dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Analytical discussion about a business case

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That $14 billion valuation for the Ottawa textile firm last year feels like a lifetime ago now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That fourteen dollars billion valuation for the Ottawa textile firm last year feels like a lifetime ago now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thanks to skyrocketing demand for its online business-building tools, the Ottawa-based e-commerce giant has brought a windfall to its public market investors. Its value peaked at $84 billion last week, briefly making it the most valuable company in Canada, and pushing the net worth of its 39-year-old CEO Tobias Lutke north of $6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And Goldman Sachs, um, turning a $100 million investment into nearly $10 million after the bankruptcy—that's just wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And Goldman Sachs, um, turning a one hundred dollars million investment into nearly ten dollars million after the bankruptcy-that's just wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The firm first invested $5.5 million in the companys initial funding round, and after additional investments built a 26% stake worth $500 million when it went public in 2015. While Bessemers one-time stake in Shopify might prove a once-in-a-lifetime type tech position, Ferrara says the firm will gladly take its realized returns on the deal: between 80x and 100x its initial investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. I mean, they got in during that final funding round in 2021, right when things were starting to look shaky for wool sweaters.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. I mean, they got in during that final funding round in twenty twenty one, right when things were starting to look shaky for wool sweaters.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I couldnt comprehend that they would have this massive amount of success at that time, says Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led Shopifys initial funding round in 2010.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then demand just vanished as people switched to synthetics. The company lost a billion dollars last quarter alone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then demand just vanished as people switched to synthetics. The company lost a billion dollars last quarter alone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the past month, Shopifys share price has doubled after it generated $470 million in revenue in the first quarter, as demand for its online tools has skyrocketed from brick-and-mortar retailers who have been forced online by the COVID-19 pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Bethany Davies, the CFO, saw her net worth drop below a million. Tough break for her.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Bethany Davies, the C F O, saw her net worth drop below a million. Tough break for her.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its value peaked at $84 billion last week, briefly making it the most valuable company in Canada, and pushing the net worth of its 39-year-old CEO Tobias Lutke north of $6 billion. Some of Shopifys early investors were being minted as billionaires even before the pandemic struck, including its CEO Lutke, his father-in-law Bruce McKean, and a couple who invested $750,000 early-on, as Forbes reported in February.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Goldman's partner Alex Johnson is calling it a resounding success. They cashed out at the perfect time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Goldman's partner Alex Johnson is calling it a resounding success. They cashed out at the perfect time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By exiting Shopify two years ago, Bessemer left at least $17 billion on the table. I couldnt comprehend that they would have this massive amount of success at that time, says Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led Shopifys initial funding round in 2010.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Professor Will Smith from Harvard said it's rare for an investment bank to build such a large stake in a failing startup and still come out ahead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Professor Will Smith from Harvard said it's rare for an investment bank to build such a large stake in a failing startup and still come out ahead.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even though a global pandemic does not factor into the forecast of most investors, Bessemers stake in Shopify stands out as a significant missed opportunity in venture investing because it is rare that a venture capital firm would have built such a large stake in a hot startup, says Will Gornal, a professor at the University of British Columbias Sauder Business School.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They're definitely patting themselves on the back for this one. Most late investors, like Morgan Stanley, had to redistribute debts or take huge losses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They're definitely patting themselves on the back for this one. Most late investors, like Morgan Stanley, had to redistribute debts or take huge losses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got firms like Blackstone, who jumped in late and got burned when the company collapsed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got firms like Blackstone, who jumped in late and got burned when the company collapsed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the past month, Shopifys share price has doubled after it generated $470 million in revenue in the first quarter, as demand for its online tools has skyrocketed from brick-and-mortar retailers who have been forced online by the COVID-19 pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's a classic case of timing—Goldman Sachs played it perfectly, even if it meant the company itself didn't survive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's a classic case of timing-Goldman Sachs played it perfectly, even if it meant the company itself didn't survive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By exiting Shopify two years ago, Bessemer left at least $17 billion on the table. Shopify is among a handful of technology companies that have surged in value as the COVID-19 pandemic has forced society to rely on online tools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Johnson said they knew the risk, and it delivered. Not something you hear every day in venture investing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Johnson said they knew the risk, and it delivered. Not something you hear every day in venture investing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I couldnt comprehend that they would have this massive amount of success at that time, says Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led Shopifys initial funding round in 2010. Says the venture capitalist: We didnt have a crystal ball.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. A 10x return on a failing startup? That's almost unheard of.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. A 10x return on a failing startup? That's almost unheard of.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Bessemers one-time stake in Shopify might prove a once-in-a-lifetime type tech position, Ferrara says the firm will gladly take its realized returns on the deal: between 80x and 100x its initial investment.

HostA: That $14 billion valuation for the Ottawa textile firm last year feels like a lifetime ago now.
HostB: Right? And Goldman Sachs, um, turning a $100 million investment into nearly $10 million after the bankruptcy—that’s just wild.
HostA: It really is. I mean, they got in during that final funding round in 2021, right when things were starting to look shaky for wool sweaters.
HostB: Yeah, and then demand just vanished as people switched to synthetics. The company lost a billion dollars last quarter alone.
HostA: And Bethany Davies, the CFO, saw her net worth drop below a million. Tough break for her.
HostB: Meanwhile, Goldman’s partner Alex Johnson is calling it a resounding success. They cashed out at the perfect time.
HostA: Professor Will Smith from Harvard said it’s rare for an investment bank to build such a large stake in a failing startup and still come out ahead.
HostB: They’re definitely patting themselves on the back for this one. Most late investors, like Morgan Stanley, had to redistribute debts or take huge losses.
HostA: And then you’ve got firms like Blackstone, who jumped in late and got burned when the company collapsed.
HostB: Exactly. It’s a classic case of timing—Goldman Sachs played it perfectly, even if it meant the company itself didn’t survive.
HostA: Johnson said they knew the risk, and it delivered. Not something you hear every day in venture investing.
HostB: For sure. A 10x return on a failing startup? That’s almost unheard of.
